results.title: Life on a sheep farm
results.creator_credit: Ronald Mason and Australian Geography Academy Film Production
results.brief_description: Life on ‘Strathearn’ a farm owned by the Ferguson family, near Ruffy, Victoria, where high quality merino sheep are bred. Land must be cleared, fenced, the fences constantly patrolled for breaks and rabbit holes, and fertilised to produce better pastures, silage and hay. Shows lambing season, shearing, baling the wool, drenching the sheep. Breeding is important if Australia is to maintain its high quality wool.

results.title: Life of the molds
results.brief_description: The microscope reveals the importance of common place moulds in our daily lives, their impact upon history, and some of the beauty and mystery to be found in the study of these tiny plants. Shows the processes of growth and reproduction, and the complex adaptations of moulds to changing environments.

results.title: Life of a queen
results.brief_description: A biography of H.M. Queen Elizabeth II. Scenes of her marriage with H.R.H. Prince Philip, of tours in Commonwealth countries, the varied duties undertaken by Her Majesty in the United Kingdom and sequences showing family life with her husband and three children.

results.title: Life of a primitive people: Africa
results.brief_description: Shows the characteristics of a primitive society, and the interventions and discoveries made by man in prehistoric times. Clarifies the meaning of ‘primitive’ by showing the pattern of life in uncivilized regions of Africa. Shows activities such as weaving and pottery-making embodying thought and skill without technology.

results.title: Life of a Philippine family
results.brief_description: An account of family life in a rural area of the Philippines. The family is that of Carlos, a rice farmer, his wife and two children. Observes Carlos at work in his rice field, his wife shopping and preparing meals for the family, the children as they go to school and assist their parents.

results.title: Life is short
results.creator_credit: Stephen Hearst, Unesco and United Nations
results.brief_description: Contrasts the surplus in rich lands, with the chronic malnutritian and near-starvation in the poor. Relates U.N. family efforts to assure a basic and healthy diet for all; and the problem of production, distribution and social adjustment involved; the “Freedom from Hunger” campaign. U Thant tells of the urgency and the target involved in the U. N.’s Development Decade.

results.title: Life is for living
results.creator_credit: Filmpartnership and Guide Dog Association of Victoria
results.brief_description: Blindness is not such a great problem when you learn to overcome it. Some of the ways to do this are through the use of guide dogs, canes or sonic guides; other senses must be utilised to the full. The film also shows blind people leading normal lives and makes suggestions for fund raising.

results.title: Life in the woodlot
results.creator_credit: Dalton Muir, Hugh O'Connor and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A surprising peek into the hidden world of the underbrush where silent, relentless rivalry is concealed by overhanging foliage or carpets of woodland flowers. What the film brings into focus is a pyramid of life in which lower orders of fauna sustain and support the higher orders. In the plant world we see a similar struggle for supremacy.

results.title: Life in the Sahara
results.creator_credit: Clifford J. Kamen Productions and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A view of life in the cities, on the farms and in the nomad caravans of the Sahara Desert. How trains, trucks, cars and aeroplanes carry supplies to the cities and camel caravans transport food and supplies to remote tribes. Emphasises the importance of water to the desert inhabitants and shows a diver risking his life to keep an artesian well free from clogging sand.

results.title: Life in the Pyrenees
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional and J. Arthur Rank Organisation
results.brief_description: The annual round of events in the daily lives of the local peasantry. In winter the mountains are covered with snow; when spring comes, shepherds move village animals to fresh pastures in the hills. Throughout the summer the animals roam over mountain pasture; butter and cheese making, cutting and hauling of timber and harvesting takes place in this season. The life of the village is quickened in tempo by the near approach of winter.
